Operator estimates for the crushed ice problem

Andrii Khrabustovskyi Institut für Numerische Mathematik, Technische Universität Graz, 8010 Graz, Austria khrabustovskyi@math.tugraz.at  and  Olaf Post Fachbereich 4 – Mathematik, Universität Trier, 54286 Trier, Germany olaf.post@uni-trier.de
Abstract.

Let ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} be the Dirichlet Laplacian in the domain Ωε:=Ω∖(∪iDi​ε)assignsubscriptΩ𝜀Ωsubscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon}:=\Omega\setminus\left(\cup_{i}D_{i\varepsilon}\right). Here Ω⊂ℝnΩsuperscriptℝ𝑛\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{n} and {Di​ε}isubscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀𝑖\{D_{i\varepsilon}\}_{i} is a family of tiny identical holes (“ice pieces”) distributed periodically in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} with period ε𝜀\varepsilon. We denote by cap⁡(Di​ε)capsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\operatorname{cap}(D_{i\varepsilon}) the capacity of a single hole. It was known for a long time that −ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} converges to the operator −ΔΩ+qsubscriptΔΩ𝑞-\Delta_{\Omega}+q in strong resolvent sense provided the limit q:=limε→0cap⁡(Di​ε)​ε−nassign𝑞subscript→𝜀0capsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛q:=\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\operatorname{cap}(D_{i\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n} exists and is finite. In the current contribution we improve this result deriving estimates for the rate of convergence in terms of operator norms. As an application, we establish the uniform convergence of the corresponding semi-groups and (for bounded ΩΩ\Omega) an estimate for the difference of the k𝑘k-th eigenvalue of −ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} and −ΔΩε+qsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀𝑞-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}+q. Our proofs relies on an abstract scheme for studying the convergence of operators in varying Hilbert spaces developed previously by the second author.

Keywords: crushed ice problem; homogenization; norm resolvent convergence; operator estimates; varying Hilbert spaces

2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary 58J50; Secondary 35B27, 35P15, 47A10

1. Introduction

In the current work we revisit one of the classical problems in homogenization theory – homogenization of the Dirichlet Laplacian in a domain with a lot of tiny holes. It is also known as crushed ice problem. Below, we briefly recall the setting of this problem and the main result.

Let ΩΩ\Omega be an open domain in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} (n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2) and {Di​ε}isubscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀𝑖\left\{D_{i\varepsilon}\right\}_{i} be a family of small holes. The holes are identical (up to a rigid motion) and are distributed evenly in ΩΩ\Omega along the ε𝜀\varepsilon-periodic cubic lattice – see Figure 1. We set

Ωε:=Ω∖(⋃iDi​ε¯).assignsubscriptΩ𝜀Ωsubscript𝑖¯subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\displaystyle\Omega_{\varepsilon}:=\Omega\setminus\Bigl{(}\bigcup_{i}\overline{{D_{i\varepsilon}}}\Bigr{)}.

The domain ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon} is depicted in Figure 1. More precise description of this domain will be given in the next section.

In ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon} we study the following problem:

−ΔΩε​uε+uε=f↾Ωε,subscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀subscript𝑢𝜀subscript𝑢𝜀𝑓subscript↾subscriptΩ𝜀absent\displaystyle-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}u_{\varepsilon}+u_{\varepsilon}=f{\restriction}_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}},

where ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} is the Dirichlet Laplacian in ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon}, f∈𝖫2​(Ω)𝑓subscript𝖫2Ωf\in\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega) is a given function, f↾Ωεsubscript↾subscriptΩ𝜀𝑓absentf{\restriction}_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} is the restriction of f𝑓f to ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon}. The goal is to describe the behaviour of the solution uεsubscript𝑢𝜀u_{\varepsilon} to this problem as ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\to 0.

It turns out that the result depends on the limit q:=limε→0cap⁡(Di​ε)​ε−nassign𝑞subscript→𝜀0capsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛q:=\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\operatorname{cap}(D_{i\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n} being finite or infinite (here cap⁡(Di​ε)capsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\operatorname{cap}(D_{i\varepsilon}) is the capacity of a single hole, see (8) for details). Namely, if q=∞𝑞q=\infty then ‖uε‖𝖫2​(Ωε)→0→subscriptnormsubscript𝑢𝜀subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀0\|u_{\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\to 0 as ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\to 0. Otherwise, if q<∞𝑞q<\infty, ‖uε−u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)→0→subscriptnormsubscript𝑢𝜀𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀0\|u_{\varepsilon}-u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\to 0 as ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\to 0, where u𝑢u is the solution to the problem

−ΔΩ​u+q​u+u=f.subscriptΔΩ𝑢𝑞𝑢𝑢𝑓-\Delta_{\Omega}u+qu+u=f.

This result was proven independently by V.A. Marchenko, E.Ya. Khruslov [MK64] (the case q<∞𝑞q<\infty), J. Rauch, M. Taylor [RT75] (the cases q=0𝑞0q=0 and q=∞𝑞q=\infty) and D. Cioranescu, F. Murat [CM82] (all scenario) by using different tools — potential theory, capacitary methods and variational approach (the so-called Tartar’s energy method), respectively. J. Rauch and M. Taylor also treated the case of randomly distributed holes under assumptions resembling the case q>0𝑞0q>0 in a deterministic case; the pioneer result in this direction was obtained by M. Kac in [Kac74], who investigated the case of uniformly distributed holes.

Note, that this result remains valid if on the external boundary (i.e. on ∂Ω∖(⋃i∂Di​ε)Ωsubscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\partial\Omega\setminus\left(\bigcup_{i}{\partial D_{i\varepsilon}}\right)) one imposes Neumann, Robin, mixed or any other ε𝜀\varepsilon-independent boundary conditions (then −ΔΩsubscriptΔΩ-\Delta_{\Omega} is the Laplace operator subject to these conditions on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega).

Besides the resolvent convergence one can study the convergence of spectrum or the convergence of the semi-group exp⁡(ΔΩε​t)subscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀𝑡\exp(\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}t). In the later case the name crushed ice problem is indeed reasonable111Let us assume that ΩΩ\Omega is an isolated container occupied by a homogeneous medium, while the sets Di​εsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀D_{i\varepsilon} are regarded as a small pieces of ice. Under a certain idealization (the ice pieces do not melt and move) the heat distribution in ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon} at time t>0𝑡0t>0 is described by the function exp⁡(ΔΩε​t)​u0subscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀𝑡subscript𝑢0\exp(\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}t)u_{0}, where ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} is the Laplace operator subject to Dirichlet conditions on the boundary of the ice pieces and Neumann conditions on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega (since the container is isolated), u0subscript𝑢0u_{0} is the heat distribution at t=0𝑡0t=0.. Also domains with a lot of Dirichlet holes have interesting scattering properties (fading/solidifying obstacles, cf. [R75b, RT75]).

For more details on the topic we refer also to articles [Ba88, Be95, Kh72, Oza83, R75a, PV80], as well as to the monographs [Br02, Cha84, CPS07, MK74, MK06, S79].

In what follows, we focus on the case q<∞𝑞q<\infty.

In the language of operator theory one can reformulate the above result as follows: the operator −ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} converges to the operator −ΔΩ+qsubscriptΔΩ𝑞-\Delta_{\Omega}+q in strong resolvent sense. Strictly speaking, we are not able to treat the classical resolvent convergence (since the underlying operators act in different Hilbert spaces), but we have its natural analogue for varying domains with Ωε⊂ΩsubscriptΩ𝜀Ω\Omega_{\varepsilon}\subset\Omega:

∀f∈𝖫2​(Ω):‖(−ΔΩε+I)−1​Jε​f−Jε​(−ΔΩ+q+I)−1​f‖𝖫2​(Ωε)→0​ as ​ε→0,:for-all𝑓subscript𝖫2Ω→subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscript𝐽𝜀superscriptsubscriptΔΩ𝑞I1𝑓subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀0 as 𝜀→0\displaystyle\forall f\in\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega):\ \|(-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}(-\Delta_{\Omega}+q+\mathrm{I})^{-1}f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\to 0\text{ as }\varepsilon\to 0, (1)

where Jε​f:=f↾Ωεassignsubscript𝐽𝜀𝑓𝑓subscript↾subscriptΩ𝜀absentJ_{\varepsilon}f:=f{\restriction}_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}.

In the recent preprint [DCR17] the authors improved (1) by proving (a kind of) norm resolvent convergence, namely

‖Jε′​(−ΔΩε+I)−1−(−ΔΩ+q+I)−1​Jε′‖ℒ​(𝖫2​(Ωε),𝖫2​(Ω))→0​ as ​ε→0,→subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀superscriptsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀I1superscriptsubscriptΔΩ𝑞I1subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀ℒsubscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscript𝖫2Ω0 as 𝜀→0\displaystyle\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}(-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-(-\Delta_{\Omega}+q+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}),\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega))}\to 0\text{ as }\varepsilon\to 0, (2)

where Jε′:𝖫2​(Ωε)→𝖫2​(Ω):subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀→subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscript𝖫2ΩJ^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\colon\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})\to\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega) is the operator of extension by zero. The authors assumed that Di​εsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀D_{i\varepsilon} are balls, distributed ε𝜀\varepsilon-periodically in ΩΩ\Omega. For bounded ΩΩ\Omega their proof resembles the variational approach developed in [CM82], for unbounded ΩΩ\Omega they also utilize a rapid decay of the Green’s function of −Δ+IΔI-\Delta+\mathrm{I}.

In the current work we extend the result of [DCR17] providing an estimate for the rate of convergence in (2) (see Theorem 2.5 below). We also improve (1) (see Theorem 2.3) deriving the operator estimate

‖(−ΔΩε+I)−1​Jε−Jε​(−ΔΩ+q+I)−1‖ℒ​(𝖫2​(Ω),𝖫2​(Ωε))≤4​δε,subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀superscriptsubscriptΔΩ𝑞I1ℒsubscript𝖫2Ωsubscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀4subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\|(-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}-J_{\varepsilon}(-\Delta_{\Omega}+q+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega),\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}))}\leq 4\delta_{\varepsilon},

where δε=|q−limε→0cap⁡(Dε)​ε−n|+γεsubscript𝛿𝜀𝑞subscript→𝜀0capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛subscript𝛾𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}=\left|q-\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n}\right|+\gamma_{\varepsilon} with γε=o​(1)subscript𝛾𝜀𝑜1\gamma_{\varepsilon}=o(1) depending on the dimension n𝑛n (for the “physical” cases n=2𝑛2n=2 and n=3𝑛3n=3 one has γε=𝒪​(ε​ln⁡ε)subscript𝛾𝜀𝒪𝜀𝜀\gamma_{\varepsilon}=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon\ln\varepsilon) and γε=𝒪​(ε)subscript𝛾𝜀𝒪𝜀\gamma_{\varepsilon}=\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon), respectively).

As a consequence of our main results, we establish uniform convergence of the corresponding semi-groups and (for bounded ΩΩ\Omega) an estimate for the difference between the k𝑘k-th eigenvalue of −ΔΩεsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}} and −ΔΩ+qsubscriptΔΩ𝑞-\Delta_{\Omega}+q — see Theorems 2.6–2.7.

Let us stress that in all our results (except Theorem 2.7) we do not assume that the domain ΩΩ\Omega is bounded.

Our proofs are based on the abstract scheme for studying the convergence of operators in varying Hilbert spaces which was developed by the second author of the present article in [P06] and in more detail in the monograph [P12].

Before proceeding to the main part of the work let us mention several related results:

  • •

    Some estimates for the rate of convergence in (1) were obtained in [CPS07, §16]. Namely, assuming that n=3𝑛3n=3, Di​εsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀D_{i\varepsilon} are balls of radius ε3superscript𝜀3\varepsilon^{3} (that is cap⁡(Di​ε)​ε−3=4​π=qcapsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀superscript𝜀34𝜋𝑞\operatorname{cap}(D_{i\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-3}=4\pi=q) distributed ε𝜀\varepsilon-periodically, and the function f𝑓f belongs to the Hölder class 𝖢0,𝔞​(Ω¯)superscript𝖢0𝔞¯Ω\mathsf{C}^{0,\mathfrak{a}}(\overline{\Omega}), the authors derived the estimates

    ‖(−ΔΩε+I)−1​Jε​f−Jε​(−ΔΩ+q+I)−1​f‖𝖫2​(Ωε)≤C​ε​‖f‖𝖢0,𝔞​(Ω¯).subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscript𝐽𝜀superscriptsubscriptΔΩ𝑞I1𝑓subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀𝐶𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓superscript𝖢0𝔞¯Ω\displaystyle\|(-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}(-\Delta_{\Omega}+q+\mathrm{I})^{-1}f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\leq{C}\varepsilon\|f\|_{\mathsf{C}^{0,\mathfrak{a}}(\overline{\Omega})}.
    ‖(−ΔΩε+I)−1​Jε​f−Jε​φε​(−ΔΩ+q+I)−1​f‖𝖧1​(Ωε)≤C​ε​‖f‖𝖢0,𝔞​(Ω¯),subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝜑𝜀superscriptsubscriptΔΩ𝑞I1𝑓superscript𝖧1subscriptΩ𝜀𝐶𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓superscript𝖢0𝔞¯Ω\displaystyle\|(-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}\varphi_{\varepsilon}(-\Delta_{\Omega}+q+\mathrm{I})^{-1}f\|_{\mathsf{H}^{1}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\leq{C}\varepsilon\|f\|_{\mathsf{C}^{0,\mathfrak{a}}(\overline{\Omega})}, (3)

    where φεsubscript𝜑𝜀\varphi_{\varepsilon} is the operator of multiplication by a certain cut-off function.

  • •

    (3)-like estimates were also obtained in [Be95]. In this work the holes are distributed ε𝜀\varepsilon-periodically in a bounded domain Ω⊂ℝnΩsuperscriptℝ𝑛\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{n} (n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2), no special assumptions on the geometry of holes are imposed. Let f∈𝖫∞​(Ω)𝑓subscript𝖫Ωf\in\mathsf{L}_{\infty}(\Omega). Then one has the estimate

    ‖(−ΔΩε)−1​Jε​f−Jε​ψε​(−ΔΩ+q)−1​f‖𝖧1​(Ωε)≤Λε​‖f‖𝖫∞​(Ω),limε→0Λε=0,formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscriptΩ𝜀1subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝜓𝜀superscriptsubscriptΔΩ𝑞1𝑓superscript𝖧1subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptΛ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝖫Ωsubscript→𝜀0subscriptΛ𝜀0\displaystyle\|(-\Delta_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}\psi_{\varepsilon}(-\Delta_{\Omega}+q)^{-1}f\|_{\mathsf{H}^{1}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\leq\Lambda_{\varepsilon}\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{\infty}(\Omega)},\ \lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\Lambda_{\varepsilon}=0,

    where the small factor ΛεsubscriptΛ𝜀\Lambda_{\varepsilon} is expressed in terms of the first eigenvalue of the Laplace operator on a period cell subject to the Dirichlet conditions on the hole boundary and the periodic conditions on the external part of the period cell boundary; the function ψεsubscript𝜓𝜀\psi_{\varepsilon} is built on the basis of the corresponding eigenfunction.

  • •

    One can also study a surface distribution of holes, i.e. holes being located near some hypersurface ΓΓ\Gamma intersecting ΩΩ\Omega. This problem was first considered in [MK64]; it was proved that the limit operator is −ΔΩ+q​δΓsubscriptΔΩ𝑞subscript𝛿Γ-\Delta_{\Omega}+q\delta_{\Gamma}. Here q∈𝖫∞​(Γ)𝑞subscript𝖫Γq\in\mathsf{L}_{\infty}(\Gamma) is a positive function, and δΓsubscript𝛿Γ\delta_{\Gamma} is a delta-distribution supported on ΓΓ\Gamma. For the case n=2𝑛2n=2, the norm resolvent convergence with estimates on the rate of convergence were obtained in [BCD16], where even more general elliptic operators were treated. The proofs in [BCD16] rely on variational formulations for the pre-limit and the homogenized resolvent equations (the key object of their analysis is a certain integral identity associated with the difference of the resolvents). Note that the method we use in the current works allows to treat surface distributions of holes as well. Nevertheless, to simplify the presentation, we focus on the bulk distribution of holes only.

  • •

    Operator estimates in homogenization theory is a rather young topic. The classical homogenization problem concerning elliptic operators of the form

    𝒜ε=−div​(A​(.ε)​∇),where A​(⋅) is a ℤn-periodic function,subscript𝒜𝜀div𝐴.𝜀∇where A(⋅) is a ℤn-periodic function,\displaystyle\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}=-\mathrm{div}\left(A\Bigl{(}\frac{.}{\varepsilon}\Bigr{)}\nabla\right),\text{where $A(\cdot)$ is a $\mathbb{Z}^{n}$-periodic function,}

    was first treated in [BS04, BS07, Gr04, Gr06, Zh05a, Zh05b, ZhP05], see the recent papers [ZhP16, S16] for further references. In particular, the article [Zh05b] deals with a perturbation which is defined by rescaling an abstract periodic measure. The technique developed in [Zh05b] can be applied for deriving operator estimates is the case of periodically perforated domains provided the sizes of holes and distances between them are of the same smallness order (evidently, this does not hold for the problem we study in the current paper). Operator estimates were also obtained for elliptic operators with frequently alternating boundary conditions (see, e.g., [BBC10]), for problems in domains with oscillating boundary [BCFP13], or for the “double-porosity” model in [CK17]. For more results we refer to the paper [BCD16] containing a comprehensive overview on operator estimates in homogenization theory.

  • •

    In [AP17] we treat (possibly non-compact) manifolds with an increasing (even infinite) number of balls removed (similarly as in [RT75]), and show operator estimates using similar methods as in this article.

2. Setting of the problem and main results

Let n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2 and let Ω⊂ℝnΩsuperscriptℝ𝑛\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{n} be a domain (not necessarily bounded) with 𝖢2superscript𝖢2\mathsf{C}^{2}-boundary ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega. We also assume that there exists a constant θΩ>0subscript𝜃Ω0\theta_{\Omega}>0 such that the following map is injective on ∂Ω×[0,θ]Ω0𝜃\partial\Omega\times[0,\theta] provided θ<θΩ𝜃subscript𝜃Ω\theta<\theta_{\Omega}:

(x,t)↦x+t​ν​(x)maps-to𝑥𝑡𝑥𝑡𝜈𝑥\displaystyle(x,t)\mapsto x+t\nu(x) (4)

where ν:∂Ω→𝕊n−1:𝜈→Ωsuperscript𝕊𝑛1\nu\colon\partial\Omega\to\mathbb{S}^{n-1} the unit inward-pointing normal vector field on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega.

Additionaly, we require ΩΩ\Omega to be uniformly regular in the sense of Browder [Br59]. This requirement is automatically fulfilled, for example, for domains with compact smooth boundaries or for compact, smooth perturbations of half-spaces. Under this assumption the Dirichlet Laplacian in ΩΩ\Omega defined via

dom⁡(ΔΩ)=𝖧2​(Ω)∩𝖧01​(Ω),ΔΩ​f:=Δ​fformulae-sequencedomsubscriptΔΩsuperscript𝖧2Ωsubscriptsuperscript𝖧10ΩassignsubscriptΔΩ𝑓Δ𝑓\operatorname{dom}(\Delta_{\Omega})=\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)\cap\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega),\quad\Delta_{\Omega}f:=\Delta f

is a self-adjoint operator (see, e.g., the recent paper [BLLR17] for more details and references on this issue).

We note, that our results remain valid under less restrictive assumptions on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega, see Remark 4.8 below.

In what follows we denote by C𝐶C, C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} etc. generic constants depending only on the dimension n𝑛n.

We set □:=(−1/2,1/2)nassign□superscript1212𝑛\square:=(-1/2,1/2)^{n}.

Now we describe a family of holes in ΩΩ\Omega (see Figure 2). Let Dεsubscript𝐷𝜀D_{\varepsilon} be a Lipschitz domain in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} depending on a small parameter ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. We denote by dεsubscript𝑑𝜀d_{\varepsilon} the radius of the smallest ball containing Dεsubscript𝐷𝜀D_{\varepsilon}. It is assumed that

(hence, in particular, dε=o​(ε)subscript𝑑𝜀𝑜𝜀d_{\varepsilon}=o(\varepsilon)). For i∈ℤn𝑖superscriptℤ𝑛i\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}, let Di​εsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀D_{i\varepsilon} be a set enjoying the following properties:

Di​ε​ coinsides with ​Dε​ up to a rigid motion,subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀 coinsides with subscript𝐷𝜀 up to a rigid motion\displaystyle D_{i\varepsilon}\text{ coinsides with }D_{\varepsilon}\text{ up to a rigid motion},

where B​(Di​ε)𝐵subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀B(D_{i\varepsilon}) is the smallest ball containing Di​εsubscript𝐷𝑖𝜀D_{i\varepsilon} (the radius of this ball is dεsubscript𝑑𝜀d_{\varepsilon}).

Finally, we set

Ωε:=Ω∖(⋃i∈ℐεDi​ε¯),assignsubscriptΩ𝜀Ωsubscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀¯subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\displaystyle\Omega_{\varepsilon}:=\Omega\setminus\left(\bigcup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\overline{{D_{i\varepsilon}}}\right),

where

ℐε:={i∈ℤn:□i​ε⊂Ω},assignsubscriptℐ𝜀conditional-set𝑖superscriptℤ𝑛subscript□𝑖𝜀Ω\displaystyle\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}:=\left\{i\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}:\ \square_{i\varepsilon}\subset\Omega\right\},

i.e. the set of those indices for which the rescaled unit cell □i​εsubscript□𝑖𝜀\square_{i\varepsilon} is entirely in ΩΩ\Omega (with positive distance to ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega). The domain ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon} is depicted in Figure 1.

By 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} we denote the Dirichlet Laplacian on ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon}, i.e. the operator acting in the Hilbert space 𝖫2​(Ωε)subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}) associated with the closed densely defined positive sesquilinear form

𝔞ε​[u,v]:=∫Ωε∇u⋅∇v¯​d​x,dom⁡(𝔞ε):=𝖧01​(Ωε).formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝔞𝜀𝑢𝑣subscriptsubscriptΩ𝜀⋅∇𝑢∇¯𝑣d𝑥assigndomsubscript𝔞𝜀subscriptsuperscript𝖧10subscriptΩ𝜀\displaystyle\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}[u,v]:=\int_{\Omega_{\varepsilon}}\nabla u\cdot\nabla\bar{v}\,\mathrm{d}x,\qquad\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}):=\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}).

Our goal is to describe the behaviour of the resolvent (𝒜ε+I)−1superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}+\mathrm{I})^{-1} as ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\to 0 under the assumption that the following limit exists and is finite:

q=limε→0cap⁡(Dε)εn,𝑞subscript→𝜀0capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛\displaystyle q=\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\frac{\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})}{\varepsilon^{n}}, (7)

where cap⁡(Dε)capsubscript𝐷𝜀\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon}) is the capacity of the set Dεsubscript𝐷𝜀D_{\varepsilon}. Recall (see, e.g., [T11]), that for n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 the capacity of a set D⊂ℝn𝐷superscriptℝ𝑛D\subset\mathbb{R}^{n} is defined via

cap⁡(D)=∫ℝn|∇H​(x)|2​dx,cap𝐷subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛superscript∇𝐻𝑥2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\operatorname{cap}(D)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}|\nabla H(x)|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}x, (8)

where H𝐻H is a solution to the problem

{Δ​H​(x)=0,x∈ℝn∖D¯,H​(x)=1,x∈∂D,H​(x)→0,|x|→∞.casesΔ𝐻𝑥0𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛¯𝐷𝐻𝑥1𝑥𝐷→𝐻𝑥0→𝑥\displaystyle\begin{cases}\Delta H(x)=0,&x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus\overline{{D}},\\ H(x)=1,&x\in\partial D,\\ H(x)\to 0,&|x|\to\infty.\end{cases} (9)

One has also the following variational characterization of the capacity, namely

cap⁡(D)=min​∫ℝn|∇u​(x)|2​dx,cap𝐷subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛superscript∇𝑢𝑥2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\operatorname{cap}(D)=\min\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}|\nabla u(x)|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}x, (10)

where the minimum is taken over u∈𝖢0∞​(ℝn)𝑢superscriptsubscript𝖢0superscriptℝ𝑛u\in\mathsf{C}_{0}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{n}) being equal to 111 on a neighbourhood of D𝐷D.

For n=2𝑛2n=2 the right-hand-side of (10) is zero for an arbitrary domain D𝐷D, hence we need a modified definition. It is as follows:

cap⁡(D)=∫B1|∇H​(x)|2​dx,cap𝐷subscriptsubscript𝐵1superscript∇𝐻𝑥2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\operatorname{cap}(D)=\int_{B_{1}}|\nabla H(x)|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}x, (11)

where B1subscript𝐵1B_{1} is the unit ball concentric with B​(D)𝐵𝐷B(D) – the smallest ball containing D𝐷D (here we assume that the set D𝐷D is small enough so that D⊂B​(D)⊂B1𝐷𝐵𝐷subscript𝐵1D\subset B(D)\subset B_{1}), H𝐻H solves the problem

{Δ​H​(x)=0,x∈B1∖D¯,H​(x)=1,x∈∂D,H​(x)=0,x∈∂B1.casesΔ𝐻𝑥0𝑥subscript𝐵1¯𝐷𝐻𝑥1𝑥𝐷𝐻𝑥0𝑥subscript𝐵1\displaystyle\begin{cases}\Delta H(x)=0,&x\in B_{1}\setminus\overline{D},\\ H(x)=1,&x\in\partial D,\\ H(x)=0,&x\in\partial B_{1}.\end{cases} (12)

Further, proving the main results, we will use the following pointwice estimates for the functions H𝐻H at some positive distance from B​(D)𝐵𝐷B(D), see [MK06, Lemma 2.4].

Lemma 2.1.

Let x∈ℝn∖B​(D)¯𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛¯𝐵𝐷x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\setminus\overline{B(D)}. We denote by ρ​(x)𝜌𝑥\rho(x) the distance from x𝑥x to B​(D)𝐵𝐷B(D), and by d𝑑d the radius of B​(D)𝐵𝐷B(D). One has:

|H​(x)|≤C⋅dn−2(ρ​(x))n−2,|∇H​(x)|≤C⋅dn−2(ρ​(x))n−1as ​n≥3,|H​(x)|≤C​|ln⁡d|−1|ln⁡ρ​(x)|−1,|∇H​(x)|≤C​|ln⁡d|−1ρ​(x)as ​n=2𝐻𝑥⋅𝐶superscript𝑑𝑛2superscript𝜌𝑥𝑛2∇𝐻𝑥⋅𝐶superscript𝑑𝑛2superscript𝜌𝑥𝑛1as 𝑛3𝐻𝑥𝐶superscript𝑑1superscript𝜌𝑥1∇𝐻𝑥𝐶superscript𝑑1𝜌𝑥as 𝑛2\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{lll}\lvert{H(x)}\rvert\leq\dfrac{C\cdot d^{n-2}}{(\rho(x))^{n-2}},&\lvert{\nabla H(x)}\rvert\leq\dfrac{C\cdot d^{n-2}}{(\rho(x))^{n-1}}&\text{as }n\geq 3,\\[8.61108pt] \lvert{H(x)}\rvert\leq\dfrac{C|\ln d|^{-1}}{|\ln\rho(x)|^{-1}},&\lvert{\nabla H(x)}\rvert\leq\dfrac{C|\ln d|^{-1}}{\rho(x)}&\text{as }n=2\end{array}

provided ρ​(x)≥C0​d𝜌𝑥subscript𝐶0𝑑\rho(x)\geq C_{0}d as n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 or ρ​(x)≥exp⁡(−C0​|ln⁡d|)𝜌𝑥subscript𝐶0𝑑\rho(x)\geq\exp\left(-C_{0}\sqrt{|\ln d|}\right) as n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3,  for some C0>0subscript𝐶00C_{0}>0.

Remark 2.2.

Due to (7) one has

cap⁡(Dε)​ε−n=𝒪​(1).capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛𝒪1\displaystyle\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n}=\mathcal{O}(1). (13)

In fact, this condition also follows directly from (5). Indeed, using the monotonicity of the capacity, we get cap⁡(Dε)≤cap⁡(Bε)capsubscript𝐷𝜀capsubscript𝐵𝜀\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\leq\operatorname{cap}(B_{\varepsilon}), where Bεsubscript𝐵𝜀B_{\varepsilon} is ball of radius dεsubscript𝑑𝜀d_{\varepsilon} containing Dεsubscript𝐷𝜀D_{\varepsilon}. For this ball the function H𝐻H can be computed explicitly:

H​(x)=(dε)n−2|x|n−2​ as ​n≥3,H​(x)=ln⁡xln⁡dε​ as ​n=2,formulae-sequence𝐻𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀𝑛2superscript𝑥𝑛2 as 𝑛3𝐻𝑥𝑥subscript𝑑𝜀 as 𝑛2H(x)=\dfrac{(d_{\varepsilon})^{n-2}}{|x|^{n-2}}\text{ as }n\geq 3,\quad H(x)=\dfrac{\ln x}{\ln d_{\varepsilon}}\text{ as }n=2,

hence cap⁡(Bε)=(n−2)​|𝕊n−1|​(dε)n−2capsubscript𝐵𝜀𝑛2superscript𝕊𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀𝑛2\operatorname{cap}(B_{\varepsilon})=(n-2)|\mathbb{S}^{n-1}|(d_{\varepsilon})^{n-2} as n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 and cap⁡(Bε)=2​π​|ln⁡dε|−1capsubscript𝐵𝜀2𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀1\operatorname{cap}(B_{\varepsilon})=2\pi|\ln d_{\varepsilon}|^{-1} as n=2𝑛2n=2, hence, due to (5), we get (13).

Finally, we introduce the limiting operator 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. It acts in 𝖫2​(Ω)subscript𝖫2Ω\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega) and is defined by

𝒜:=−ΔΩ+q​I,dom⁡(𝒜):=dom⁡(ΔΩ)=𝖧2​(Ω)∩𝖧01​(Ω).formulae-sequenceassign𝒜subscriptΔΩ𝑞Iassigndom𝒜domsubscriptΔΩsuperscript𝖧2Ωsubscriptsuperscript𝖧10Ω\mathcal{A}:=-\Delta_{\Omega}+q\mathrm{I},\quad\operatorname{dom}(\mathcal{A}):=\operatorname{dom}(\Delta_{\Omega})=\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)\cap\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega).

By 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} we denote the associated form:

𝔞​[u,v]:=∫Ω(∇u⋅∇v¯+q​u​v¯)​dx,dom⁡(𝔞):=𝖧01​(Ω).formulae-sequenceassign𝔞𝑢𝑣subscriptΩ⋅∇𝑢∇¯𝑣𝑞𝑢¯𝑣differential-d𝑥assigndom𝔞subscriptsuperscript𝖧10Ω\displaystyle\mathfrak{a}[u,v]:=\int_{\Omega}\left(\nabla u\cdot\nabla\bar{v}+q\,u\bar{v}\right)\,\mathrm{d}x,\qquad\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}):=\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega).

The operators 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} act in different Hilbert spaces, namely ℋε:=𝖫2​(Ωε)assignsubscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}:=\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}) and ℋ:=𝖫2​(Ω)assignℋsubscript𝖫2Ω\mathcal{H}:=\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega), respectively. Therefore we are not able to apply the usual notion of resolvent convergence and thus a suitable modification is needed. There are many ways how to do this in a “smart” way. For example (cf. [IOS89, Vai05]), one can treat the behaviour of the operator

(𝒜ε+I)−1​Jε−Jε​(𝒜+I)−1∈ℒ​(ℋ,ℋε),superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1ℒℋsubscriptℋ𝜀(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}-J_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\in\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}),

where Jε:ℋ→ℋε:subscript𝐽𝜀→ℋsubscriptℋ𝜀J_{\varepsilon}\colon\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon} is a suitable bounded linear operator satisfying

∀f∈ℋ:‖Jε​f‖ℋε→‖f‖ℋ​ as ​ε→0.:for-all𝑓ℋ→subscriptnormsubscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscriptℋ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓ℋ as 𝜀→0\displaystyle\forall f\in\mathcal{H}:\ \|J_{\varepsilon}f\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}}\to\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}\text{ as }\varepsilon\to 0. (14)

It is natural to choose the operator Jεsubscript𝐽𝜀J_{\varepsilon} as the operator of restriction to ΩεsubscriptΩ𝜀\Omega_{\varepsilon}, i.e.

(Jε​f)​(x)={f​(x),x∈Ωε,0,x∈⋃i∈ℐεDi​ε.subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓𝑥cases𝑓𝑥𝑥subscriptΩ𝜀0𝑥subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\displaystyle(J_{\varepsilon}f)(x)=\begin{cases}f(x),&x\in\Omega_{\varepsilon},\\ 0,&x\in\displaystyle\bigcup\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}D_{i\varepsilon}.\end{cases} (15)

Due to (5) one has for each compact set K⊂ℝn𝐾superscriptℝ𝑛K\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}

∑i:Di​ε⊂K|Di​ε|≤αε​|K|,αε=o​(1)​ does not depend on ​K,formulae-sequencesubscript:𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀𝐾subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀subscript𝛼𝜀𝐾subscript𝛼𝜀𝑜1 does not depend on 𝐾\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i:\,D_{i\varepsilon}\subset K}|D_{i\varepsilon}|\leq\alpha_{\varepsilon}|K|,\ \alpha_{\varepsilon}=o(1)\text{ does not depend on }K, (16)

where |K|𝐾|K| stands for the Lebesgue measure of K𝐾K. Hence, evidently, (14) holds. The results of [CM82, MK64, RT75] can be reformulated as follows:

∀f∈ℋ:limε→0∥(𝒜ε+I)−1Jεf−Jε(𝒜+I)−1f∥ℋε→0,\forall f\in\mathcal{H}\colon\quad\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\left\|(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}f\right\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}}\to 0,

i.e. one has a kind of strong resolvent convergence.

Now, we can state our main result.

Theorem 2.3.

One has

‖(𝒜ε+I)−1​Jε−Jε​(𝒜+I)−1‖ℒ​(ℋ,ℋε)≤4​δε,subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1ℒℋsubscriptℋ𝜀4subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}-J_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})}\leq 4\delta_{\varepsilon},

where δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon} is defined by

δε=|cap⁡(Dε)​ε−n−q|+CΩ,κ,β⋅{ε​|ln⁡ε|,n=2,ε,n=3ε1−β,β>0,n=4,max⁡{ε;dε​ε−1},n≥5,subscript𝛿𝜀capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛𝑞⋅subscript𝐶Ω𝜅𝛽cases𝜀𝜀𝑛2𝜀𝑛3superscript𝜀1𝛽𝛽0𝑛4𝜀subscript𝑑𝜀superscript𝜀1𝑛5\displaystyle\delta_{\varepsilon}=|\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n}-q|+C_{\Omega,\kappa,\beta}\cdot\begin{cases}\varepsilon|\ln\varepsilon|,&n=2,\\[4.30554pt] \varepsilon,&n=3\\[4.30554pt] \displaystyle\varepsilon^{1-\beta},\ \beta>0,&n=4,\\[4.30554pt] \max\limits\left\{\varepsilon;\,{d_{\varepsilon}}{\varepsilon}^{-1}\right\},&n\geq 5,\end{cases} (17)

and the constant CΩ,κ,βsubscript𝐶Ω𝜅𝛽C_{\Omega,\kappa,\beta} depends on the domain ΩΩ\Omega, the relative distance κ𝜅\kappa of the obstacles from the period cell boundary (see (6)), and, in the case n=4𝑛4n=4, on β𝛽\beta.

Remark 2.4.

Via the same arguments as in Remark 2.2 one gets (dε)n−2​ε−n≥C>0superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀𝑛2superscript𝜀𝑛𝐶0(d_{\varepsilon})^{n-2}\varepsilon^{-n}\geq C>0 provided q>0𝑞0q>0, hence, using the definition of δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}, we obtain

q>0,n≥5:δε=|cap(Dε)ε−n−q|+CΩ,κε2/(n−2).q>0,\ n\geq 5:\quad\delta_{\varepsilon}=|\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n}-q|+C_{\Omega,\kappa}\varepsilon^{2/(n-2)}.

Let Jε′:ℋε→ℋ:superscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀′→subscriptℋ𝜀ℋJ_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}\colon\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}\to\mathcal{H} be the operator of extension by zero:

(Jε′​u)​(x)={u​(x),x∈Ωε,0,x∈⋃i∈ℐεDi​ε.superscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀′𝑢𝑥cases𝑢𝑥𝑥subscriptΩ𝜀0𝑥subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀\displaystyle(J_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}u)(x)=\begin{cases}u(x),&x\in\Omega_{\varepsilon},\\ 0,&x\in\displaystyle\bigcup\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}D_{i\varepsilon}.\end{cases} (18)

Then the main result of [DCR17] is equivalent to

‖Jε′​(𝒜ε+I)−1−(𝒜+I)−1​Jε′‖ℒ​(ℋε,ℋ)→0,ε→0.formulae-sequence→subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1superscript𝒜I1subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀ℋ0→𝜀0\left\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathcal{H})}\to 0,\ \varepsilon\to 0.

The next theorem gives an improvement of this statement.

Theorem 2.5.

One has

‖Jε′​(𝒜ε+I)−1−(𝒜+I)−1​Jε′‖ℒ​(ℋε,ℋ)≤6​δε,subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1superscript𝒜I1subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀ℋ6subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathcal{H})}\leq 6\delta_{\varepsilon},

where δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon} is defined in (17). Moreover,

‖Jε′​(𝒜ε+I)−1​Jε−(𝒜+I)−1‖ℒ​(ℋ,ℋ)≤9​δε,subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1ℒℋℋ9subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}-(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H},\mathcal{H})}\leq 9\delta_{\varepsilon},
‖(𝒜ε+I)−1−Jε​(𝒜+I)−1​Jε′‖ℒ​(ℋε,ℋε)≤13​δε.subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀subscriptℋ𝜀13subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-J_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})}\leq 13\delta_{\varepsilon}.

One important applications of the norm resolvent convergence is the uniform convergence of semi-groups generated by 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Namely, we can approximate exp⁡(−𝒜ε​t)subscript𝒜𝜀𝑡\exp(-\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}t) in terms of simpler operators exp⁡(−𝒜​t)𝒜𝑡\exp(-\mathcal{A}t), Jεsubscript𝐽𝜀J_{\varepsilon} and Jε′subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}:

Theorem 2.6.

One has for each t>0𝑡0t>0:

‖exp⁡(−𝒜ε​t)−Jε​exp⁡(−𝒜​t)​Jε′‖ℒ​(ℋε,ℋε)≤ct​δε,subscriptnormsubscript𝒜𝜀𝑡subscript𝐽𝜀𝒜𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀′ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀subscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝑐𝑡subscript𝛿𝜀\left\|{\exp(-\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}t)}-J_{\varepsilon}{\exp(-\mathcal{A}t)}J_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})}\leq c_{t}\delta_{\varepsilon},

where δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon} is defined in (17), and the constant ctsubscript𝑐𝑡c_{t} depends only on t𝑡t.

Another important application is the Hausdorff convergence of spectra, see [DCR17]. Using Theorem 2.3 we are able to extend this result by obtaining an estimate for the difference between the corresponding eigenvalues. Namely, let the domain ΩΩ\Omega be bounded. We denote by {λk,ε}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘𝜀𝑘ℕ\{\lambda_{k,\varepsilon}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} and {λk}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘𝑘ℕ\{\lambda_{k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} the sequences of the eigenvalues of 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, respectively, arranged in the ascending order and repeated according to their multiplicities.

Theorem 2.7.

For each k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N} one has

limε→0λk,ε=λk,subscript→𝜀0subscript𝜆𝑘𝜀subscript𝜆𝑘\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\lambda_{k,\varepsilon}=\lambda_{k}, (19)

moreover

|λk,ε−λk|≤4​Cε​(λk,ε+1)​(λk+1)​δε,subscript𝜆𝑘𝜀subscript𝜆𝑘4subscript𝐶𝜀subscript𝜆𝑘𝜀1subscript𝜆𝑘1subscript𝛿𝜀|\lambda_{k,\varepsilon}-\lambda_{k}|\leq 4C_{\varepsilon}(\lambda_{k,\varepsilon}+1)(\lambda_{k}+1)\delta_{\varepsilon}, (20)

where δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon} is defined in (17), and |Cε|≤Csubscript𝐶𝜀𝐶|C_{\varepsilon}|\leq C, limε→0Cε=1subscript→𝜀0subscript𝐶𝜀1\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}C_{\varepsilon}=1.

In the next section we introduce an abstract scheme, which then will be applied for the proof of the above theorems.

3. Abstract framework

In this section we present an abstract scheme for studying the convergence of operators in varying Hilbert spaces. It was developed by the second author of the present article in [P06] and in more detail in the monograph [P12] (see also the later work [MNP13], where non-self-adjoint operators were treated).

Let ℋℋ\mathcal{H} and ℋεsubscriptℋ𝜀\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon} be two separable Hilbert spaces. Note, that within this section ℋεsubscriptℋ𝜀\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon} is just a notation for some Hilbert space, which (in general) differs from the space ℋℋ\mathcal{H}, i.e. the sub-index ε𝜀\varepsilon does not mean that this space depends on a small parameter. Of course, further we will use the results of this section for ε𝜀\varepsilon-dependent space ℋε=𝖫2​(Ωε)subscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}=\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}).

Let 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} and 𝔞εsubscript𝔞𝜀\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon} be closed, densely defined, non-negative sesquilinear forms in ℋℋ\mathcal{H} and ℋεsubscriptℋ𝜀\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}, respectively. We denote by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} the non-negative, self-adjoint operators associated with 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} and 𝔞εsubscript𝔞𝜀\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}, respectively.

Associated with the operator 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, we can introduce a natural scale of Hilbert spaces ℋksuperscriptℋ𝑘\mathcal{H}^{k} defined via the abstract Sobolev norm:

ℋk=dom⁡𝒜k/2,‖f‖ℋk≔‖f‖k≔‖(𝒜+I)k/2​f‖ℋ.formulae-sequencesuperscriptℋ𝑘domsuperscript𝒜𝑘2≔subscriptnorm𝑓superscriptℋ𝑘subscriptnorm𝑓𝑘≔subscriptnormsuperscript𝒜I𝑘2𝑓ℋ\displaystyle\mathcal{H}^{k}=\operatorname{dom}\mathcal{A}^{k/2},\quad\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}^{k}}\coloneqq\|f\|_{k}\coloneqq\|{(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{k/2}f}\|_{\mathcal{H}}.

In particular, we have ℋ0=ℋsuperscriptℋ0ℋ\mathcal{H}^{0}=\mathcal{H} with ‖f‖ℋ0=‖f‖ℋsubscriptnorm𝑓superscriptℋ0subscriptnorm𝑓ℋ\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}^{0}}=\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}, ℋ1=dom⁡(𝔞)superscriptℋ1dom𝔞\mathcal{H}^{1}=\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}) with ‖f‖ℋ1=(𝔞​[f,f]+‖f‖ℋ2)1/2subscriptnorm𝑓superscriptℋ1superscript𝔞𝑓𝑓superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑓ℋ212\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}^{1}}=(\mathfrak{a}[f,f]+\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}^{2})^{1/2}, and ℋ2=dom⁡(𝒜)superscriptℋ2dom𝒜\mathcal{H}^{2}=\operatorname{dom}(\mathcal{A}) with ‖f‖ℋ2=‖𝒜​f+f‖ℋsubscriptnorm𝑓superscriptℋ2subscriptnorm𝒜𝑓𝑓ℋ\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}^{2}}=\|\mathcal{A}f+f\|_{\mathcal{H}}.

Similarly, we denote by ℋεksuperscriptsubscriptℋ𝜀𝑘\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}^{k} the scale of Hilbert spaces associated with 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}. The corresponding norms will be denoted by ∥⋅∥ℋεk\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}^{k}}.

We now need pairs of so-called identification or transplantation operators acting on the Hilbert spaces and later also pairs of identification operators acting on the form domains.

Definition 3.1 ((see [P06, App.] or [P12, Ch. 4])).

Let δε≥0subscript𝛿𝜀0\delta_{\varepsilon}\geq 0 and k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}. (C5)
Remark 3.2.

For δε=0subscript𝛿𝜀0\delta_{\varepsilon}=0 the definition above implies that the operators 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} are unitary equivalent. Indeed, (C2)–(C4​b4b{}_{4\text{b}}) assure that the operator Jεsubscript𝐽𝜀J_{\varepsilon} is unitary with the inverse Jε′subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}; due to (C1​a1a{}_{1\text{a}})–(C1​b1b{}_{1\text{b}}) Jε1subscriptsuperscript𝐽1𝜀J^{1}_{\varepsilon} and Jε1⁣′subscriptsuperscript𝐽1′𝜀J^{1\prime}_{\varepsilon} are the restrictions of Jεsubscript𝐽𝜀J_{\varepsilon} and Jε1subscriptsuperscript𝐽1𝜀J^{1}_{\varepsilon} onto dom⁡(𝔞)dom𝔞\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}) and dom⁡(𝔞ε)domsubscript𝔞𝜀\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}), respectively. Hence, in view of (C5), Jεsubscript𝐽𝜀J_{\varepsilon} realises the unitary equivalence of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}.

Now, we present the main implications of the definition of δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}-closeness.

Theorem 3.3 ([P06, Th. A.5]).

One has

‖(𝒜ε+I)−1​Jε−Jε​(𝒜+I)−1‖ℒ​(ℋ,ℋε)≤4​δε,subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1ℒℋsubscriptℋ𝜀4subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}-J_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})}\leq 4\delta_{\varepsilon},

provided conditions (C1​a1a{}_{1\text{a}}), (C1​b1b{}_{1\text{b}}), (C2), and (C5) hold with k≤2𝑘2k\leq 2.

Remark 3.4.

Let 𝒜εsubscript𝒜𝜀\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon} (ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0), 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be non-negative self-adjoint operators in the same Hilbert space ℋℋ\mathcal{H}, and let 𝔞εsubscript𝔞𝜀\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon} and 𝔞𝔞\mathfrak{a} be the corresponding sesquilinear forms. We assume that dom⁡(𝔞ε)=dom⁡(𝔞)domsubscript𝔞𝜀dom𝔞\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon})=\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}) and

|𝔞ε​(f,u)−𝔞​(f,u)|≤δε​𝔞​[f,f]+‖f‖ℋ​𝔞ε​[u,u]+‖u‖ℋ,∀f,u∈dom⁡(𝔞),formulae-sequencesubscript𝔞𝜀𝑓𝑢𝔞𝑓𝑢subscript𝛿𝜀𝔞𝑓𝑓subscriptnorm𝑓ℋsubscript𝔞𝜀𝑢𝑢subscriptnorm𝑢ℋfor-all𝑓𝑢dom𝔞\displaystyle\left|\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}(f,u)-\mathfrak{a}(f,u)\right|\leq\delta_{\varepsilon}\sqrt{\mathfrak{a}[f,f]+\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}}\sqrt{\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}[u,u]+\|u\|_{\mathcal{H}}},\ \forall f,u\in\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a}), (21)

where δε→0→subscript𝛿𝜀0\delta_{\varepsilon}\to 0 as ε→0→𝜀0\varepsilon\to 0. Due to (21) (ℋ,𝔞)ℋ𝔞(\mathcal{H},\mathfrak{a}) and (ℋ,𝔞ε)ℋsubscript𝔞𝜀(\mathcal{H},\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}) are δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}-close of order 111 with respect to the identity maps Jε,Jε′subscript𝐽𝜀superscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀′J_{\varepsilon},J_{\varepsilon}^{\prime} (on ℋℋ\mathcal{H}) and Jε1,Jε1⁣′superscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀1superscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀1′J_{\varepsilon}^{1},J_{\varepsilon}^{1\prime} (on dom⁡(𝔞)dom𝔞\operatorname{dom}(\mathfrak{a})). Then by Theorem 3.3

‖(𝒜ε+I)−1−(𝒜+I)−1‖ℒ​(ℋ)→0.→subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1superscript𝒜I1ℒℋ0\displaystyle\left\|(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}({\mathcal{H}})}\to 0. (22)

In fact, it would suffice for (22) if (21) is satisfied whenever f=u𝑓𝑢f=u, see Theorem VI.3.6 in T. Kato’s monograph [Kat66]. In this sense, Theorem 3.3 can be regarded as a generalization of this classical result to the setting of varying spaces.

Theorem 3.5 ([P06, Th. A.8]).

Let U⊂ℝ+¯𝑈¯subscriptℝU\subset\overline{{\mathbb{R}_{+}}} be an open set containing either σ​(𝒜)𝜎𝒜\sigma(\mathcal{A}) or σ​(𝒜ε)𝜎subscript𝒜𝜀\sigma(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}). Let ψ:ℝ+¯→ℂ:𝜓→¯subscriptℝℂ\psi\colon\overline{{\mathbb{R}_{+}}}\to\mathbb{C} be a bounded measurable function, continuous on U𝑈U and such that the limit limλ→∞ψ​(λ)subscript→𝜆𝜓𝜆\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\psi(\lambda) exists.

Then there exists ηψ​(δ)>0subscript𝜂𝜓𝛿0\eta_{\psi}(\delta)>0 with ηψ​(δ)→0→subscript𝜂𝜓𝛿0\eta_{\psi}(\delta)\to 0 as δ→0→𝛿0\delta\to 0 such that

‖ψ​(𝒜ε)​Jε−Jε​ψ​(𝒜)‖ℒ​(ℋ,ℋε)≤ηψ​(δε)subscriptnorm𝜓subscript𝒜𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀𝜓𝒜ℒℋsubscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝜂𝜓subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|\psi(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon})J_{\varepsilon}-J_{\varepsilon}\psi(\mathcal{A})\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})}\leq\eta_{\psi}(\delta_{\varepsilon}) (23)

for all pairs (ℋ,𝔞)ℋ𝔞(\mathcal{H},\mathfrak{a}) and (ℋε,𝔞ε)subscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝔞𝜀(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}), which are δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}-close of order k≤2𝑘2k\leq 2.

Remark 3.6.

The important example of the function ψ𝜓\psi satisfying the requirements of the above theorem is ψ​(λ)=exp⁡(−λ​t)𝜓𝜆𝜆𝑡\psi(\lambda)=\exp(-\lambda t), t>0𝑡0t>0 is a parameter. Another important example is the function ψ=𝟏(α,β)𝜓subscript1𝛼𝛽\psi=\mathbf{1}_{(\alpha,\beta)} – the characteristic function of the interval (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta) with α,β∉σ​(𝒜)𝛼𝛽𝜎𝒜\alpha,\beta\notin\sigma(\mathcal{A}) or α,β∉σ​(𝒜ε)𝛼𝛽𝜎subscript𝒜𝜀\alpha,\beta\notin\sigma(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}). In this case Theorem 3.5 gives the closeness of the spectral projections.

Corollary 3.8.

One has

‖Jε′​(𝒜ε+I)−1−(𝒜+I)−1​Jε′‖ℒ​(ℋε,ℋ)≤6​δε,subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1superscript𝒜I1subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀ℋ6subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathcal{H})}\leq 6\delta_{\varepsilon},
‖Jε′​(𝒜ε+I)−1​Jε−(𝒜+I)−1‖ℒ​(ℋ,ℋ)≤9​δε,subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1ℒℋℋ9subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J_{\varepsilon}-(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H},\mathcal{H})}\leq 9\delta_{\varepsilon},
‖(𝒜ε+I)−1−Jε​(𝒜+I)−1​Jε′‖ℒ​(ℋε,ℋε)≤13​δεsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀I1subscript𝐽𝜀superscript𝒜I1subscriptsuperscript𝐽′𝜀ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀subscriptℋ𝜀13subscript𝛿𝜀\displaystyle\left\|(\mathcal{A_{\varepsilon}}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}-J_{\varepsilon}(\mathcal{A}+\mathrm{I})^{-1}J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})}\leq 13\delta_{\varepsilon}

provided (ℋ,𝔞)ℋ𝔞(\mathcal{H},\mathfrak{a}) and (ℋε,𝔞ε)subscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝔞𝜀(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}) are δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}-close of order k≤2𝑘2k\leq 2.

For “good enough” functions the last statement of Theorem 3.7 can be improved. Evidently the function ψ​(λ)=exp⁡(−λ​t)𝜓𝜆𝜆𝑡\psi(\lambda)=\exp(-\lambda t) (t>0𝑡0t>0) satisfies the requirements of the theorem below.

Theorem 3.9 ([MNP13, Th. 3.7]222Actually, (24) is proven in [MNP13, Th. 3.7] only for the case k=1𝑘1k=1. For k=2𝑘2k=2 the proof is repeated word-by-word since it relies only on the last estimate in Corollary 3.8.).

Let ΣΘ:={z∈ℂ:|arg⁡(z+1)|<Θ}assignsubscriptΣΘconditional-set𝑧ℂ𝑧1Θ\Sigma_{\Theta}:=\{z\in\mathbb{C}:\ |\arg(z+1)|<\Theta\} with Θ∈(0,π)Θ0𝜋\Theta\in(0,\pi) and ψ:ΣΘ→ℂ:𝜓→subscriptΣΘℂ\psi:\Sigma_{\Theta}\to\mathbb{C} be a holomorphic function satisfying ψ​(z)=𝒪​(|z|−μ)𝜓𝑧𝒪superscript𝑧𝜇\psi(z)=\mathcal{O}(|z|^{-\mu}) for some μ>12𝜇12\mu>\frac{1}{2}. Let (ℋ,𝔞)ℋ𝔞(\mathcal{H},\mathfrak{a}) and (ℋε,𝔞ε)subscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝔞𝜀(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}) be δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}-close of order k≤2𝑘2k\leq 2. Then

Remark 3.10.

In fact, (24) is valid even for less regular functions. For instance, it holds for ψ=𝟏(α,β)𝜓subscript1𝛼𝛽\psi=\mathbf{1}_{(\alpha,\beta)} as in Remark 3.6, see [P12, Sec. 4.5, Cor. 4.5.15].

The last result concerns the convergence of spectra in general. For two compact sets X,Y⊂ℝ𝑋𝑌ℝX,Y\subset\mathbb{R} we denote by distH⁡(X,Y)subscriptdistH𝑋𝑌\operatorname{dist}_{\mathrm{H}}(X,Y) the Hausdorff distance between these sets, i.e.

distH⁡(X,Y)=max⁡{supx∈Xdist⁡(x,Y);supy∈Ydist⁡(y,X)},subscriptdistH𝑋𝑌subscriptsupremum𝑥𝑋dist𝑥𝑌subscriptsupremum𝑦𝑌dist𝑦𝑋\operatorname{dist}_{\mathrm{H}}(X,Y)=\max\Bigl{\{}\sup_{x\in X}\,\operatorname{dist}(x,Y);\,\sup_{y\in Y}\,\operatorname{dist}(y,X)\Bigr{\}},

where dist⁡(x,Y)=infy∈Y|x−y|dist𝑥𝑌subscriptinfimum𝑦𝑌𝑥𝑦\operatorname{dist}(x,Y)=\inf_{y\in Y}\lvert{x-y}\rvert.

Remark 3.11.

Let {Xε⊂ℝ}εsubscriptsubscript𝑋𝜀ℝ𝜀\{X_{\varepsilon}\subset\mathbb{R}\}_{\varepsilon} be a family of compact domains and

distH⁡(Xε,X)→0​ as ​ε→0→subscriptdistHsubscript𝑋𝜀𝑋0 as 𝜀→0\displaystyle\operatorname{dist}_{\mathrm{H}}\left(X_{\varepsilon},X\right)\to 0\text{ as }\varepsilon\to 0 (25)

for some compact domain X⊂ℝ𝑋ℝX\subset\mathbb{R}. It is easy to prove (see, e.g., [P12, Proposition A.1.6]) that (25) holds iff the following two conditions are fulfilled:

  • (i)

    Let λ0∈ℝ∖Xsubscript𝜆0ℝ𝑋\lambda_{0}\in\mathbb{R}\setminus X. Then there exists d>0𝑑0d>0 such that Xε∩{λ:|λ−λ0|<d}=∅subscript𝑋𝜀conditional-set𝜆𝜆subscript𝜆0𝑑X_{\varepsilon}\cap\{\lambda:\ |\lambda-\lambda_{0}|<d\}=\varnothing.

    Let λ0∈Xsubscript𝜆0𝑋\lambda_{0}\in X. Theorem 3.12 ([P06, Th. A.13]).

There exists η​(δ)>0𝜂𝛿0\eta(\delta)>0 with η​(δ)→0→𝜂𝛿0\eta(\delta)\to 0 as δ→0→𝛿0\delta\to 0 such that

for all pairs (ℋ,𝔞)ℋ𝔞(\mathcal{H},\mathfrak{a}) and (ℋε,𝔞ε)subscriptℋ𝜀subscript𝔞𝜀(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}) which are δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}-close of some order k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}.

4. Proof of the main results

Then Theorem 2.3 follows immediately from Theorem 3.3, Theorem 2.5 follows from Corollary 3.8, and Theorem 2.6 follows from Theorem 2. The proof of Theorem 2.7 needs an additional step. and therefore conditions (C3​a3a{}_{3\text{a}})–(C3​b3b{}_{3\text{b}}) are valid as well with δε=0subscript𝛿𝜀0\delta_{\varepsilon}=0. Thus, it remains to check the non-trivial conditions (C1​a1a{}_{1\text{a}}), (C4​a4a{}_{4\text{a}}) and (C5).

The following Friedrichs- and Poincare-type inequalities will be frequently used further.

Lemma 4.1.

One has

∀v∈𝖧01(□i​ε):∥v∥𝖫2​(□i​ε)2≤Cε2∥∇v∥𝖫2​(□i​ε)2,\displaystyle\forall v\in\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\square_{i\varepsilon}):\quad\|v\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}\leq C\varepsilon^{2}\|\nabla v\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}, (26)
∀v∈𝖧1(□i​ε):∥v−⟨v⟩□i​ε∥𝖫2​(□i​ε)2≤Cε2∥∇v∥𝖫2​(□i​ε)2.\displaystyle\forall v\in\mathsf{H}^{1}(\square_{i\varepsilon}):\quad\|v-\langle v\rangle_{\square_{i\varepsilon}}\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}\leq C\varepsilon^{2}\|\nabla v\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}. (27)
Proof.

By the min-max principle

ΛεD=min⁡{‖∇u‖𝖫2​(□i​ε)2‖u‖𝖫2​(□i​ε)2:u∈𝖧01​(□i​ε)∖{0}},superscriptsubscriptΛ𝜀D:subscriptsuperscriptnorm∇𝑢2subscript𝖫2subscript□𝑖𝜀subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑢2subscript𝖫2subscript□𝑖𝜀𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝖧10subscript□𝑖𝜀0\displaystyle\Lambda_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{D}}=\min\left\{\frac{\|\nabla u\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}}{\|u\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}}:\ u\in\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\square_{i\varepsilon})\setminus\{0\}\right\},
ΛεN=min⁡{‖∇u‖𝖫2​(□i​ε)2‖u‖𝖫2​(□i​ε)2:u∈𝖧1​(□i​ε)∖{0},∫□i​εu​(x)​dx=0},superscriptsubscriptΛ𝜀N:subscriptsuperscriptnorm∇𝑢2subscript𝖫2subscript□𝑖𝜀subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑢2subscript𝖫2subscript□𝑖𝜀formulae-sequence𝑢superscript𝖧1subscript□𝑖𝜀0subscriptsubscript□𝑖𝜀𝑢𝑥differential-d𝑥0\displaystyle\Lambda_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{N}}=\min\left\{\frac{\|\nabla u\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}}{\|u\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}}:\ u\in\mathsf{H}^{1}(\square_{i\varepsilon})\setminus\{0\},\ \int\limits_{\square_{i\varepsilon}}u(x)\,\mathrm{d}x=0\right\},

where ΛεDsuperscriptsubscriptΛ𝜀D\Lambda_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{D}} (respectively, ΛεNsuperscriptsubscriptΛ𝜀N\Lambda_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{N}}) is the first (respectively, the second) eigenvalue of the Dirichlet (respectively, the Neumann) Laplacian on □i​εsubscript□𝑖𝜀\square_{i\varepsilon}. Straightforward calculations gives

λεD=n​(πε)2,λεN=(πε)2,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝜀D𝑛superscript𝜋𝜀2superscriptsubscript𝜆𝜀Nsuperscript𝜋𝜀2\displaystyle\lambda_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{D}}=n\left(\frac{\pi}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2},\qquad\lambda_{\varepsilon}^{\mathrm{N}}=\left(\frac{\pi}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2},

hence we easily get the required inequalities (26)–(27). ∎

4.1. Proof of (C1​a1a{}_{1\text{a}})

4.2. Proof of (C4​a4a{}_{4\text{a}})

We need the following lemma, which was proven in [MK06, Lem. 4.9 and Rem. 4.2)].

Lemma 4.2.

Let D⊂ℝn𝐷superscriptℝ𝑛D\subset\mathbb{R}^{n} be a bounded convex domain, and let D1,D2⊂Dsubscript𝐷1subscript𝐷2𝐷D_{1},D_{2}\subset D be measurable subsets with |D2|≠0subscript𝐷20|D_{2}|\not=0. Then

‖v‖𝖫2​(D1)2≤2​|D1||D2|​‖v‖𝖫2​(D2)2+C​(diam⁡(D))n+1​|D1|1/n|D2|​‖∇v‖𝖫2​(D)2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑣2subscript𝖫2subscript𝐷12subscript𝐷1subscript𝐷2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑣2subscript𝖫2subscript𝐷2𝐶superscriptdiam𝐷𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐷11𝑛subscript𝐷2subscriptsuperscriptnorm∇𝑣2subscript𝖫2𝐷\|v\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(D_{1})}\leq\frac{2|D_{1}|}{|D_{2}|}\|v\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(D_{2})}+C\frac{(\operatorname{diam}(D))^{n+1}|D_{1}|^{1/n}}{|D_{2}|}\|\nabla v\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(D)}

for all v∈𝖧1​(D)𝑣superscript𝖧1𝐷v\in\mathsf{H}^{1}(D), where C𝐶C depends only on the dimension n𝑛n.

Let f∈𝖫2​(Ω)𝑓subscript𝖫2Ωf\in\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega). Applying Lemma 4.2 with v:=fassign𝑣𝑓v:=f and D:=□i​εassign𝐷subscript□𝑖𝜀D:=\square_{i\varepsilon}, D1:=Di​εassignsubscript𝐷1subscript𝐷𝑖𝜀D_{1}:=D_{i\varepsilon}, D2:=□i​εassignsubscript𝐷2subscript□𝑖𝜀D_{2}:=\square_{i\varepsilon} we obtain

4.3. Proof of the form estimate (C5)

We will show that (C5) holds with k=2𝑘2k=2.

Recall that ℋ2superscriptℋ2\mathcal{H}^{2} is a Hilbert space consisting of functions from dom⁡(𝒜)=𝖧2​(Ω)∩𝖧01​(Ω)dom𝒜superscript𝖧2Ωsubscriptsuperscript𝖧10Ω\operatorname{dom}(\mathcal{A})=\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)\cap\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega) with scalar product (f,g)ℋ2:=(𝒜​f+f,𝒜​g+g)ℋassignsubscript𝑓𝑔superscriptℋ2subscript𝒜𝑓𝑓𝒜𝑔𝑔ℋ(f,g)_{\mathcal{H}^{2}}:=(\mathcal{A}f+f,\mathcal{A}g+g)_{\mathcal{H}}.

Since ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega is 𝖢2superscript𝖢2\mathsf{C}^{2}-smooth, we can apply standard elliptic regularity theory (see, e.g., [GT77]): namely, the ℋ2superscriptℋ2\mathcal{H}^{2}-norm is equivalent to the 𝖧2​(Ω)superscript𝖧2Ω\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)-norm, i.e. there is CΩ>0subscript𝐶Ω0C_{\Omega}>0 such that for each f∈dom⁡(𝒜)𝑓dom𝒜f\in\operatorname{dom}(\mathcal{A}) we have

‖f‖𝖧2​(Ω)≤CΩ​‖f‖ℋ2subscriptnorm𝑓superscript𝖧2Ωsubscript𝐶Ωsubscriptnorm𝑓superscriptℋ2\displaystyle\|f\|_{\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)}\leq C_{\Omega}\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}^{2}} (35)

(the fulfilment of (35) for noncompact ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega is due to the uniform regularity of ΩΩ\Omega).

Note, that this is the only estimate in our proof in which the constant depends on the domain ΩΩ\Omega. This results to ΩΩ\Omega-dependence of the constant standing in the definition of δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon}.

Let f∈dom⁡(𝒜)𝑓dom𝒜f\in\operatorname{dom}(\mathcal{A}), u∈𝖧01​(Ωε)𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝖧10subscriptΩ𝜀u\in\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega_{\varepsilon}). One has:

|𝔞ε​[u,Jε1​f]−𝔞​[Jε1⁣′​u,f]|≤|∑i∈ℐε(∇u,∇Pi​εf)𝖫2​(Yi​ε)|+|∑i∈ℐε(∇u,∇Qi​εf)𝖫2​(Yi​ε)+q(u,f)𝖫2​(Ωε)|=:𝒥ε,1+𝒥ε,2.\left|\mathfrak{a}_{\varepsilon}[u,J_{\varepsilon}^{1}f]-\mathfrak{a}[J_{\varepsilon}^{1\prime}u,f]\right|\\ \leq\left|\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}(\nabla u,\nabla P_{i\varepsilon}f)_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(Y_{i\varepsilon})}\right|+\left|\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}(\nabla u,\nabla Q_{i\varepsilon}f)_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(Y_{i\varepsilon})}+q(u,f)_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\right|=:\mathcal{J}_{\varepsilon,1}+\mathcal{J}_{\varepsilon,2}.

4.3.1. Estimates for 𝒥ε,1subscript𝒥𝜀1\mathcal{J}_{\varepsilon,1}

One has, taking into account that |χi​ε​(x)|≤1subscript𝜒𝑖𝜀𝑥1|\chi_{i\varepsilon}(x)|\leq 1:

𝒥ε,1≤|∑i∈ℐε(∇u,χi​ε∇f)𝖫2​(supp⁡(χi​ε))|+|∑i∈ℐε(∇u,(f−fi​ε)∇χi​ε)𝖫2​(supp⁡(χi​ε))|≤‖∇u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​((∑i∈ℐε‖∇f‖𝖫2​(supp⁡(χi​ε))2)12+(∑i∈ℐε‖(f−fi​ε)​∇χi​ε‖𝖫2​(Yi​ε)2)12)\mathcal{J}_{\varepsilon,1}\leq\Bigl{|}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}(\nabla u,\chi_{i\varepsilon}\nabla f)_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\operatorname{supp}(\chi_{i\varepsilon}))}\Bigr{|}+\Bigl{|}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}(\nabla u,(f-f_{i\varepsilon})\nabla\chi_{i\varepsilon})_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\operatorname{supp}(\chi_{i\varepsilon}))}\Bigr{|}\\ \leq\|\nabla u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\left(\Bigl{(}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\|\nabla f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\operatorname{supp}(\chi_{i\varepsilon}))}^{2}\Bigr{)}^{\frac{1}{2}}+\Bigl{(}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\|(f-f_{i\varepsilon})\nabla\chi_{i\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(Y_{i\varepsilon})}^{2}\Bigr{)}^{\frac{1}{2}}\right) (36)

Applying Lemma 4.2 with v:=∂jfassign𝑣subscript𝑗𝑓v:=\partial_{j}f, D:=□i​εassign𝐷subscript□𝑖𝜀D:=\square_{i\varepsilon}, D1:=supp⁡(χi​ε)assignsubscript𝐷1suppsubscript𝜒𝑖𝜀D_{1}:=\operatorname{supp}(\chi_{i\varepsilon}) and D2:=□i​εassignsubscript𝐷2subscript□𝑖𝜀D_{2}:=\square_{i\varepsilon}, and taking into account (5) and (35) we obtain the estimates:

n≥2:∑i∈ℐε‖∇f‖𝖫2​(supp⁡(χi​ε))2≤C​((dεε)n+ε⋅dε)​‖f‖𝖧2​(Ω)2≤C​ε2​‖f‖ℋ22,n=2:∑i∈ℐε‖∇f‖𝖫2​(supp⁡(χi​ε))2≤C​((ε2ε)2+ε⋅ε2)​‖f‖𝖧2​(Ω)2≤C​ε2​‖f‖ℋ22.:𝑛2absentsubscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscriptsuperscriptnorm∇𝑓2subscript𝖫2suppsubscript𝜒𝑖𝜀𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀𝜀𝑛⋅𝜀subscript𝑑𝜀subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2superscript𝖧2Ω𝐶superscript𝜀2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2superscriptℋ2:𝑛2absentsubscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscriptsuperscriptnorm∇𝑓2subscript𝖫2suppsubscript𝜒𝑖𝜀𝐶superscriptsuperscript𝜀2𝜀2⋅𝜀superscript𝜀2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2superscript𝖧2Ω𝐶superscript𝜀2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2superscriptℋ2\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{ll}n\geq 2:&\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\|\nabla f\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\operatorname{supp}(\chi_{i\varepsilon}))}\leq C\left(\left(\frac{d_{\varepsilon}}{\varepsilon}\right)^{n}+\varepsilon\cdot d_{\varepsilon}\right)\|f\|^{2}_{\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)}\leq C\varepsilon^{2}\|f\|^{2}_{\mathcal{H}^{2}},\\[4.30554pt] n=2:&\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\|\nabla f\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\operatorname{supp}(\chi_{i\varepsilon}))}\leq C\left(\left(\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2}+\varepsilon\cdot\varepsilon^{2}\right)\|f\|^{2}_{\mathsf{H}^{2}(\Omega)}\leq C\varepsilon^{2}\|f\|^{2}_{\mathcal{H}^{2}}.\end{array} (39)

Now, we estimate the second term in (36). One has the following Hölder-type inequality:

∀p,q∈[2,∞],1p+1q=12:∥(f−fi​ε)∇χi​ε∥𝖫2​(Yi​ε)≤∥f−fi​ε∥𝖫p​(Yi​ε)∥∇χi​ε∥𝖫q​(Yi​ε)\displaystyle\forall p,q\in[2,\infty],\ \frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=\frac{1}{2}:\,\,\|(f-f_{i\varepsilon})\nabla\chi_{i\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(Y_{i\varepsilon})}\leq\|f-f_{i\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{p}(Y_{i\varepsilon})}\|\nabla\chi_{i\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{q}(Y_{i\varepsilon})} (40)

(for p=∞𝑝p=\infty we use a convention p−1=0superscript𝑝10p^{-1}=0). Besides (8) (or (11) for n=2𝑛2n=2) there is another equivalent characterization of the capacity.

Lemma 4.5.

Let D⊂ℝn𝐷superscriptℝ𝑛D\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}, and let H𝐻H be the solution of either (9) if n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 or (12) if n=2𝑛2n=2. Then

cap⁡(D)=−∫∂D∂H∂ν​ds,cap𝐷subscript𝐷𝐻𝜈differential-d𝑠\displaystyle\operatorname{cap}(D)=-\int\limits_{\partial D}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}\,\mathrm{d}s, (57)

where ν𝜈\nu is the outward-pointing unit normal to ∂D𝐷\partial D, d​sd𝑠\,\mathrm{d}s is the area measure on ∂D𝐷\partial D.

Proof.

For n=2𝑛2n=2 the result follows from

∫∂D∂H∂ν​ds=∫∂D∂H∂ν​H​ds=−∫B1∖D¯|∇H|2​dx.subscript𝐷𝐻𝜈differential-d𝑠subscript𝐷𝐻𝜈𝐻differential-d𝑠subscriptsubscript𝐵1¯𝐷superscript∇𝐻2differential-d𝑥\int\limits_{\partial D}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}\,\mathrm{d}s=\int\limits_{\partial D}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}H\,\mathrm{d}s=-\int\limits_{B_{1}\setminus\overline{D}}|\nabla H|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}x.

Here the first equality is due to H↾∂D=1H{\restriction}_{\partial D}=1, while the second one is the Green formula, in which the surface integral over ∂B1subscript𝐵1\partial B_{1} vanishes since H↾∂B1=0H{\restriction}_{\partial B_{1}}=0, and the second volume integral vanishes since Δ​H=0Δ𝐻0\Delta H=0.

For n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 we proceed as follows. Let BRsubscript𝐵𝑅B_{R} be the ball of radius R>1𝑅1R>1 being concentric with the smallest ball containing D𝐷D. One has:

∫∂D∂H∂ν​ds=∫∂D∂H∂ν​H​ds=−∫BR∖D¯|∇H|2​dx−∫∂BR∂H∂ν​H​dssubscript𝐷𝐻𝜈differential-d𝑠subscript𝐷𝐻𝜈𝐻differential-d𝑠subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑅¯𝐷superscript∇𝐻2differential-d𝑥subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑅𝐻𝜈𝐻differential-d𝑠\displaystyle\int\limits_{\partial D}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}\,\mathrm{d}s=\int\limits_{\partial D}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}H\,\mathrm{d}s=-\int\limits_{B_{R}\setminus\overline{D}}|\nabla H|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}x-\int\limits_{\partial B_{R}}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}H\,\mathrm{d}s (58)

(in the last integral ν𝜈\nu is the inward-pointing unit normal to ∂BRsubscript𝐵𝑅\partial B_{R}). Lemma 2.1 implies the estimate

|∫∂BR∂H∂ν​H​ds|≤CRn−2.subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑅𝐻𝜈𝐻differential-d𝑠𝐶superscript𝑅𝑛2\displaystyle\left|\int\limits_{\partial B_{R}}\frac{\partial H}{\partial\nu}H\,\mathrm{d}s\right|\leq\frac{C}{R^{n-2}}. (59)

Passing to the limit R→∞→𝑅R\to\infty in (58) and taking into account (8) and (59) we arrive at the required equality (57). The lemma is proved. ∎

The remainder term ζεsubscript𝜁𝜀\zeta_{\varepsilon} is small; namely the following estimate holds:

Lemma 4.6.

One has:

|ζε|≤Cκ⋅{ε​‖∇u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​‖f‖𝖫2​(Ω),n≥3,ε​|ln⁡ε|​‖∇u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​‖f‖𝖫2​(Ω),n=2.subscript𝜁𝜀⋅subscript𝐶𝜅cases𝜀subscriptnorm∇𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝖫2Ω𝑛3𝜀𝜀subscriptnorm∇𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝖫2Ω𝑛2\displaystyle|\zeta_{\varepsilon}|\leq C_{\kappa}\cdot\begin{cases}\varepsilon\|\nabla u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)},&n\geq 3,\\[4.30554pt] \varepsilon|\ln\varepsilon|\|\nabla u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)},&n=2.\end{cases} (61)
Proof.

At first we consider the case n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3. Since Δ​Hi​ε=0Δsubscript𝐻𝑖𝜀0\Delta H_{i\varepsilon}=0 we have

Δ​(Hi​ε​χ^i​ε)=2​∇Hi​ε⋅∇χ^i​ε+Hi​ε​Δ​χ^i​ε,Δsubscript𝐻𝑖𝜀subscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀⋅2∇subscript𝐻𝑖𝜀∇subscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀subscript𝐻𝑖𝜀Δsubscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀\displaystyle\Delta(H_{i\varepsilon}\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon})=2\nabla H_{i\varepsilon}\cdot\nabla\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon}+H_{i\varepsilon}\Delta\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon},
supp⁡(Δ​(Hi​ε​χ^i​ε))⊂{x∈Yi​ε:dε+κ​ε/2≤|x−xi​ε|≤dε+κ​ε},suppΔsubscript𝐻𝑖𝜀subscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀conditional-set𝑥subscript𝑌𝑖𝜀subscript𝑑𝜀𝜅𝜀2𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖𝜀subscript𝑑𝜀𝜅𝜀\displaystyle\operatorname{supp}(\Delta(H_{i\varepsilon}\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon}))\subset\left\{x\in Y_{i\varepsilon}:\ d_{\varepsilon}+{\kappa\varepsilon}/2\leq|x-x_{i\varepsilon}|\leq d_{\varepsilon}+\kappa\varepsilon\right\},

hence, due to Lemma 2.1, (5) and |∇χ^i​ε​(x)|≤C​κ−1​ε−1∇subscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀𝑥𝐶superscript𝜅1superscript𝜀1|\nabla\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon}(x)|\leq C\kappa^{-1}\varepsilon^{-1}, |Δ​χ^i​ε​(x)|≤C​κ−2​ε−2Δsubscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀𝑥𝐶superscript𝜅2superscript𝜀2|\Delta\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon}(x)|\leq C\kappa^{-2}\varepsilon^{-2}, we get

|(Δ​(Hi​ε​χ^i​ε))​(x)|≤C​((dε)n−2εn−1⋅1κ​ε+(dε)n−2εn−2⋅1κ2​ε2)≤Cκ,Δsubscript𝐻𝑖𝜀subscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀𝑥𝐶⋅superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀𝑛2superscript𝜀𝑛11𝜅𝜀⋅superscriptsubscript𝑑𝜀𝑛2superscript𝜀𝑛21superscript𝜅2superscript𝜀2subscript𝐶𝜅\displaystyle|(\Delta(H_{i\varepsilon}\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon}))(x)|\leq C\left(\frac{(d_{\varepsilon})^{n-2}}{\varepsilon^{n-1}}\cdot\frac{1}{\kappa\varepsilon}+\frac{(d_{\varepsilon})^{n-2}}{\varepsilon^{n-2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\kappa^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right)\leq C_{\kappa}, (62)

Then, using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, (27) and (62), we obtain

|ζε|≤Cκ​(∑i∈ℐε‖Jε′​u−ui​ε‖𝖫2​(□i​ε))1/2​(∑i∈ℐε|fi​ε|2​εn)1/2≤Cκ​ε​‖∇u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​‖f‖𝖫2​(Ω).subscript𝜁𝜀subscript𝐶𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐽𝜀′𝑢subscript𝑢𝑖𝜀subscript𝖫2subscript□𝑖𝜀12superscriptsubscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝜀2superscript𝜀𝑛12subscript𝐶𝜅𝜀subscriptnorm∇𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝖫2Ω\displaystyle|\zeta_{\varepsilon}|\leq C_{\kappa}\left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\|J_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}u-u_{i\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}\right)^{1/2}\left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}|f_{i\varepsilon}|^{2}\varepsilon^{n}\right)^{1/2}\leq C_{\kappa}\varepsilon\|\nabla u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)}.

In the case n=2𝑛2n=2 Lemma 2.1 gives

|(Δ​(Hi​ε​χ^i​ε))​(x)|≤Cκ​|ln⁡ε|,Δsubscript𝐻𝑖𝜀subscript^𝜒𝑖𝜀𝑥subscript𝐶𝜅𝜀\displaystyle|(\Delta(H_{i\varepsilon}\widehat{\chi}_{i\varepsilon}))(x)|\leq C_{\kappa}|\ln\varepsilon|,

and, via the same arguments as in the case n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3, we obtain

|ζε|≤Cκ​ε​|ln⁡ε|​‖∇u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​‖f‖𝖫2​(Ω).subscript𝜁𝜀subscript𝐶𝜅𝜀𝜀subscriptnorm∇𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝖫2Ω\displaystyle|\zeta_{\varepsilon}|\leq C_{\kappa}\varepsilon|\ln\varepsilon|\|\nabla u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)}.

The lemma is proved. ∎

We need also the estimate for 𝖧01​(Ω)subscriptsuperscript𝖧10Ω\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega)-functions in a neighbourhood of ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega.

Lemma 4.7.

Let Tε=Ωε∖∪i∈ℐεYi​ε¯subscript𝑇𝜀subscriptΩ𝜀¯subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscript𝑌𝑖𝜀T_{\varepsilon}=\Omega_{\varepsilon}\setminus\overline{\cup_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}Y_{i\varepsilon}}. One has for each f∈𝖧01​(Ω)𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝖧10Ωf\in\mathsf{H}^{1}_{0}(\Omega):

‖f‖𝖫2​(Tε)≤C​ε​‖∇f‖𝖫2​(Ω).subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀𝐶𝜀subscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝖫2Ω\displaystyle\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(T_{\varepsilon})}\leq C\varepsilon\|\nabla f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)}. (63)
Proof.

We denote

Ω^ε={y∈ℝn:y=x+t​ν​(x),x∈∂Ω,t∈[0,n​ε)}subscript^Ω𝜀conditional-set𝑦superscriptℝ𝑛formulae-sequence𝑦𝑥𝑡𝜈𝑥formulae-sequence𝑥Ω𝑡0𝑛𝜀\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon}=\{y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}:\ y=x+t\nu(x),\ x\in\partial\Omega,\ t\in[0,\sqrt{n}\varepsilon)\}

(recall that ν:∂Ω→𝕊n−1:𝜈→Ωsuperscript𝕊𝑛1\nu\colon\partial\Omega\to\mathbb{S}^{n-1} is a unit inward-pointing normal vector field on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega). Note, that n𝑛\sqrt{n} is the length of the diagonal of the cube □□\square. Taking this into account one can easily deduce from the definition of the set ℐεsubscriptℐ𝜀\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon} that Tε⊂Ω^εsubscript𝑇𝜀subscript^Ω𝜀T_{\varepsilon}\subset\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon}.

Let ΔΩ^εsubscriptΔsubscript^Ω𝜀\Delta_{\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon}} be the Laplace operator on Ω^εsubscript^Ω𝜀\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon} subject to the Dirichlet conditions on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega and the Neumann conditions on ∂Ω^ε∖∂Ωsubscript^Ω𝜀Ω\partial\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon}\setminus\partial\Omega. One has the following asymptotic equality (see  [Kr14]):

infσ​(−ΔΩ^ε)=(π2​n​ε)2+CΩε+𝒪​(1),infimum𝜎subscriptΔsubscript^Ω𝜀superscript𝜋2𝑛𝜀2subscript𝐶Ω𝜀𝒪1\inf\sigma(-\Delta_{\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon}})=\left(\frac{\pi}{2\sqrt{n}\varepsilon}\right)^{2}+\frac{C_{\Omega}}{\varepsilon}+\mathcal{O}(1),

where the constant CΩsubscript𝐶ΩC_{\Omega} depends on the principal curvatures of ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega. Note, that the result of [Kr14] is obtained under the assumption that the map (4) is injective on ∂Ω×[0,n​ε]Ω0𝑛𝜀\partial\Omega\times[0,\sqrt{n}\varepsilon], that indeed holds true provided ε𝜀\varepsilon is small enough, namely ε<θΩ/n𝜀subscript𝜃Ω𝑛\varepsilon<\theta_{\Omega}/\sqrt{n}.

Hence, using the minimax principle, we get the inequality

‖f‖𝖫2​(Ω^ε)2≤C​ε2​‖∇f‖𝖫2​(Ω^ε)2,subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓2subscript𝖫2subscript^Ω𝜀𝐶superscript𝜀2subscriptsuperscriptnorm∇𝑓2subscript𝖫2subscript^Ω𝜀\displaystyle\|f\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon})}\leq C\varepsilon^{2}\|\nabla f\|^{2}_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon})}, (64)

which holds for each f∈𝖧1​(Ω^ε)𝑓superscript𝖧1subscript^Ω𝜀f\in\mathsf{H}^{1}(\widehat{\Omega}_{\varepsilon}) with f↾∂Ω=0f{\restriction}_{\partial\Omega}=0. Obviously, (63) follows from (64). ∎

Using (27), (60), (63) we obtain from (56):

𝒥ε,2≤|ζε|+|∑i∈ℐεfi​ε​ui​ε​cap⁡(Dε)−q​∑i∈ℐε(f,u)𝖫2​(Yi​ε)|+q​|(f,u)𝖫2​(Tε)|≤|ζε|+|(cap⁡(Dε)​ε−n−q)​∑i∈ℐεεn​fi​ε​ui​ε|+q​|∑i∈ℐε(fi​ε−f,u)𝖫2​(Yi​ε)|+q​|(f,u)𝖫2​(Tε)|≤|ζε|+|cap⁡(Dε)​ε−n−q|​‖f‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​‖u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)+q​(∑i∈ℐε‖f−fi​ε‖𝖫2​(□i​ε))1/2​‖u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)+q​‖f‖𝖫2​(Tε)​‖u‖𝖫2​(Tε)≤|ζε|+|cap⁡(Dε)​ε−n−q|​‖f‖𝖫2​(Ωε)​‖u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)+C​ε​‖∇f‖𝖫2​(Ω)​‖u‖𝖫2​(Ωε)+q​‖f‖𝖫2​(Tε)​‖u‖𝖫2​(Tε),subscript𝒥𝜀2subscript𝜁𝜀subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscript𝑓𝑖𝜀subscript𝑢𝑖𝜀capsubscript𝐷𝜀𝑞subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscript𝑓𝑢subscript𝖫2subscript𝑌𝑖𝜀𝑞subscript𝑓𝑢subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀subscript𝜁𝜀capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛𝑞subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝜀subscript𝑢𝑖𝜀𝑞subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝜀𝑓𝑢subscript𝖫2subscript𝑌𝑖𝜀𝑞subscript𝑓𝑢subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀subscript𝜁𝜀capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛𝑞subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝜀subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscript𝑓𝑖𝜀subscript𝖫2subscript□𝑖𝜀12subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀𝑞subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀subscript𝜁𝜀capsubscript𝐷𝜀superscript𝜀𝑛𝑞subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀𝐶𝜀subscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript𝖫2Ωsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢subscript𝖫2subscriptΩ𝜀𝑞subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑢subscript𝖫2subscript𝑇𝜀\mathcal{J}_{\varepsilon,2}\leq|\zeta_{\varepsilon}|+\left|\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}f_{i\varepsilon}u_{i\varepsilon}\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})-q\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}(f,u)_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(Y_{i\varepsilon})}\right|+q\left|(f,u)_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(T_{\varepsilon})}\right|\\ \leq|\zeta_{\varepsilon}|+|\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n}-q|\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\|u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}+q\left(\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{I}_{\varepsilon}}\|f-f_{i\varepsilon}\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\square_{i\varepsilon})}\right)^{1/2}\|u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\\ +q\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(T_{\varepsilon})}\|u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(T_{\varepsilon})}\leq|\zeta_{\varepsilon}|+|\operatorname{cap}(D_{\varepsilon})\varepsilon^{-n}-q|\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\|u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}\\ +C\varepsilon\|\nabla f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)}\|u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega_{\varepsilon})}+q\|f\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(T_{\varepsilon})}\|u\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(T_{\varepsilon})},

hence, taking into account (61), we get

𝒥ε,2≤δε​‖u‖ℋ1​‖f‖ℋ1.subscript𝒥𝜀2subscript𝛿𝜀subscriptnorm𝑢superscriptℋ1subscriptnorm𝑓superscriptℋ1\displaystyle\mathcal{J}_{\varepsilon,2}\leq\delta_{\varepsilon}\|u\|_{\mathcal{H}^{1}}\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}^{1}}. (65)

Combining estimates (55) and (65) we obtain (C5) with k=2𝑘2k=2.

Thus, we have checked the fulfilment of conditions (C1​a1a{}_{1\text{a}})–(C5), hence we immediately get Theorems 2.3–2.6.

Remark 4.8.

It is evident from the proof that the assumptions on ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega can be weakened. We use them twice: to guarantee the fulfilment of (35) (elliptic regularity) and to prove estimate (64), where we utilize the result from [Kr14]. It is well-known, that the elliptic regularity is still valid under less restrictive assumptions, for example, if ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega is compact and belongs to 𝖢1,1superscript𝖢11\mathsf{C}^{1,1} class or ΩΩ\Omega is a convex domain with Lipschitz boundary (see, e.g., [Gv85, Theorems 2.2.2.3 and 3.2.1.2]). Apparently, inequality (64) can be proved for Lipschitz domains under additional restrictions on principal curvatures.

4.4. Proof of Theorem 2.7

We will use the results of [IOS89]. Let ℋεsubscriptℋ𝜀\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon} and ℋℋ\mathcal{H} be separable Hilbert spaces, and Bε:ℋε→ℋε,B:ℋ→ℋ:subscript𝐵𝜀→subscriptℋ𝜀subscriptℋ𝜀𝐵:→ℋℋB_{\varepsilon}\colon\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}\to\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon},\ B\colon\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{H} be linear compact self-adjoint positive operators. We denote by {μk,ε}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝜀𝑘ℕ\{\mu_{k,\varepsilon}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} and {μk}k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑘ℕ\left\{\mu_{k}\right\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}} the eigenvalues of the operators Bεsubscript𝐵𝜀B_{\varepsilon} and B𝐵B, respectively, being renumbered in the descending order and with account of their multiplicity.

Theorem 4.9 ([IOS89]).

Assume that the following conditions A1−A4subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴4A_{1}-A_{4} hold:

A1.subscript𝐴1A_{1}. The linear bounded operator Jε:ℋ→ℋε:subscript𝐽𝜀→ℋsubscriptℋ𝜀J_{\varepsilon}\colon\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon} exists such that for each f∈ℋ𝑓ℋf\in\mathcal{H}

‖Jε​f‖ℋε→‖f‖ℋ​ as ​ε→0.→subscriptnormsubscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscriptℋ𝜀subscriptnorm𝑓ℋ as 𝜀→0\displaystyle\|J_{\varepsilon}f\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}}\to\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}\text{ as }\varepsilon\to 0.

A2.subscript𝐴2A_{2}. The norms ‖Bε‖ℒ​(ℋε)subscriptnormsubscript𝐵𝜀ℒsubscriptℋ𝜀\|B_{\varepsilon}\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon})} are bounded uniformly in ε𝜀\varepsilon.

A3.subscript𝐴3A_{3}. For any f∈ℋ𝑓ℋf\in\mathcal{H}: ‖Bε​Jε​f−Jε​B​f‖ℋε→0​ as ​ε→0→subscriptnormsubscript𝐵𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscript𝐽𝜀𝐵𝑓subscriptℋ𝜀0 as 𝜀→0\|B_{\varepsilon}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}Bf\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}}\to 0\text{ as }\varepsilon\to 0.

A4.subscript𝐴4A_{4}. For any family {fε∈ℋε}εsubscriptsubscript𝑓𝜀subscriptℋ𝜀𝜀\{f_{\varepsilon}\in\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}\}_{\varepsilon} with supε‖fε‖ℋε<∞subscriptsupremum𝜀subscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝜀subscriptℋ𝜀\sup_{\varepsilon}\|f_{\varepsilon}\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}}<\infty there exist a sequence (εm)msubscriptsubscript𝜀𝑚𝑚(\varepsilon_{m})_{m} and w∈ℋ𝑤ℋw\in\mathcal{H} such that ‖Bεm​fεm−Jεm​w‖ℋεm→0→subscriptnormsubscript𝐵subscript𝜀𝑚subscript𝑓subscript𝜀𝑚subscript𝐽subscript𝜀𝑚𝑤subscriptℋsubscript𝜀𝑚0\|B_{\varepsilon_{m}}f_{\varepsilon_{m}}-J_{\varepsilon_{m}}w\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon_{m}}}\to 0 and εm→0→subscript𝜀𝑚0\varepsilon_{m}\to 0 as m→∞→𝑚m\to\infty.

Then for any k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N} we have

|μk,ε−μk|≤Cε​supf‖Bε​Jε​f−Jε​B​f‖ℋε,subscript𝜇𝑘𝜀subscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝐶𝜀subscriptsupremum𝑓subscriptnormsubscript𝐵𝜀subscript𝐽𝜀𝑓subscript𝐽𝜀𝐵𝑓subscriptℋ𝜀|\mu_{k,\varepsilon}-\mu_{k}|\leq C_{\varepsilon}\sup\limits_{f}\|B_{\varepsilon}J_{\varepsilon}f-J_{\varepsilon}Bf\|_{\mathcal{H}_{\varepsilon}},

where |Cε|≤Csubscript𝐶𝜀𝐶|C_{\varepsilon}|\leq C, limε→0Cε=1subscript→𝜀0subscript𝐶𝜀1\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}C_{\varepsilon}=1, the supremum is taken over all f∈ℋ𝑓ℋf\in\mathcal{H} belonging to the eigenspace associated with μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k} and satisfying ‖f‖ℋ=1subscriptnorm𝑓ℋ1\|f\|_{\mathcal{H}}=1.

We apply this theorem with Bε=(𝒜ε+I)−1subscript𝐵𝜀superscriptsubscript𝒜𝜀𝐼1B_{\varepsilon}=(\mathcal{A}_{\varepsilon}+I)^{-1}, B=(𝒜+I)−1𝐵superscript𝒜𝐼1B=(\mathcal{A}+I)^{-1}. Thus there exist w∈𝖫2​(Ω)𝑤subscript𝖫2Ωw\in\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega) and a sequence (εm)msubscriptsubscript𝜀𝑚𝑚(\varepsilon_{m})_{m} such that ‖Jεm′​Bεm​fεm−w‖𝖫2​(Ω)→0→subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐽′subscript𝜀𝑚subscript𝐵subscript𝜀𝑚subscript𝑓subscript𝜀𝑚𝑤subscript𝖫2Ω0\|J^{\prime}_{\varepsilon_{m}}B_{\varepsilon_{m}}f_{\varepsilon_{m}}-w\|_{\mathsf{L}_{2}(\Omega)}\to 0 and εm→0→subscript𝜀𝑚0\varepsilon_{m}\to 0 as m→∞→𝑚m\to\infty, hence we immediately obtain Condition A4subscript𝐴4A_{4}.

Combining Theorems 2.3 and 4.9 we arrive at the estimate

|μk,ε−μk|≤4​Cε​δε,subscript𝜇𝑘𝜀subscript𝜇𝑘4subscript𝐶𝜀subscript𝛿𝜀\left|\mu_{k,\varepsilon}-\mu_{k}\right|\leq 4C_{\varepsilon}\delta_{\varepsilon}, (66)

where |Cε|≤Csubscript𝐶𝜀𝐶|C_{\varepsilon}|\leq C, limε→0Cε=1subscript→𝜀0subscript𝐶𝜀1\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}C_{\varepsilon}=1 and δεsubscript𝛿𝜀\delta_{\varepsilon} is given in (17). Since μk,ε=(λk,ε+1)−1subscript𝜇𝑘𝜀superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘𝜀11\mu_{k,\varepsilon}=(\lambda_{k,\varepsilon}+1)^{-1}, and μk=(λk+1)−1subscript𝜇𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘11\mu_{k}=(\lambda_{k}+1)^{-1}, (66) is equivalent to (20).

Finally, we observe that for each fixed k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}

λk,ε≤Cksubscript𝜆𝑘𝜀subscript𝐶𝑘\displaystyle\lambda_{k,\varepsilon}\leq C_{k} (67)

that follows from Theorem 3.12 and Remark 3.11 (otherwise, we will easily obtain a contradiction with Condition (ii) from this remark). (20), (67) imply (19). Theorem 2.7 is proved.
